text: thank you so much for the introduction
it really is an honor to be among such
an amazing group of young scientists oh
thank you so much for this opportunity
so the title of my talk simple materials
reimagined highlights one of the themes
of my presentation but also something
that I think is really important in
science that we don't discuss quite
enough which is the role that
imagination plays in scientific research
and innovation I personally think that
there's so much to be learned and
discovered just by looking at simple
everyday materials around us if we're
willing to reimagine their purpose and
their function so I'm really excited to
share with you an example of that from
our own research today before I get to
that I'd like to tell you a little bit
about my journey in chemistry and I kept
wanting to start this story with
dolphins which seems a little bit
strange but when I was a kid I was
totally obsessed with dolphins um so
this is a picture of me with my sister
I'm the one with the heart-shaped
glasses looking at this dolphin and if
you knew me back then you would have
thought that I'd become a marine
biologist and clearly I'm not a marine
biologist that's okay but I do largely
credit my love of dolphins all things
oceanography and my parents
encouragement of me to learn everything
that I could about it that really was
the start of my love of science I'm
chemistry specifically didn't really
come into the picture until high school
I was really fortunate to go to a
science and tech high school with
amazing teachers and resources and I
took three years of chemistry classes so
by the time I went off to college
I couldn't imagine a semester without
chemistry that coupled with my
undergraduate research experiences and I
was well on my way to my current career
path that being said there have been so
many people along the way that have
helped me
friends family mentors colleagues role
models advisors without all of them and
of course they're too many to list or to
picture here but without their help I
certainly wouldn't be where I am today
something else that I think has really
helped me in my scientific career which
I probably wouldn't have given credit to
until more recently was actually my
childhood endeavors in creative
problem-solving competitions such as
Destination ImagiNation a future
problem-solvers Odyssey of the mind and
if you're not familiar with those
programs they're just team-based
creative problem-solving competitions
where you solve open-ended problems on a
shoestring budget really short timelines
which I just did because I would had fun
I was with my friends I got to build
things which was great
in retrospect of course what I was doing
what I was I was practicing my creative
thinking abilities and I was honing my
imagination which i think has helped me
tremendously as a scientist in my
current career and so it was really
training me to look at things around me
everyday things and see them perhaps
differently so maybe a silly example
right if you gave me a Red Solo Cup
maybe I wouldn't see it as a cup maybe I
would see it as like the head of this
marionette puppet that we built which is
maybe a silly example but as scientists
this is really what we do every day
right we have to look at data we have to
look at materials and phenomena around
us we have to see things in these
materials that we've never seen before
that nobody else has seen before and we
do that by using our minds eye by using
our imagination so imagination and
creativity are incredibly important in
science I don't think people would argue
with that but I think what we should
discuss more is as a field what role we
want creativity training to play in a
formal STEM education because creative
thinking and imagination I think are
really things that we need to practice
as in order to get better and it is so
important in scientific research so now
to sort of transitioned to the research
part of the talk of course I have to
acknowledge and thank my amazing
research group and colleagues at Penn
State without them of course none of the
work that I'm about to show you
impossible so I'm really fortunate to be
able to work with such an amazing group
of people my research group primarily
focuses on design synthesis and
integration of materials for adaptive
microscale systems and we do this really
through two different materials
platforms first would be soft materials
a lot of liquids and gels
looking at how these reconfigurable
materials change their shape change
their interfaces how can we use that to
create adaptive active materials and the
second part of my research group largely
focuses on using laser direct writing
and synthesis to pattern and integrate
materials on micrometer length scales to
create more complex functional
architectures now because this talk is
relatively short I don't have a lot of
time to go into detail of all of this so
I've just chosen one story to tell you
today related to the reconfigurable
fluids and adaptive materials part of
our research so I'm gonna begin on the
next slide with a video of something
that I think many of you may have
already seen before in your daily lives
right so we begin with a petri dish and
we're going to pour warm water in it and
then put the lid onto this dish and we
see these pretty colors appear now
certainly if you work with petri dishes
in your lab almost certainly you've seen
something like this you may have also
seen this effect when you put saran wrap
over warm food for instance we're on the
inside of a water bottle and if you see
this you go oh that's really pretty but
maybe it looks like things i've seen
before maybe it's diffraction or a thin
film interference and it's very easy to
just brush this off as something
commonplace that you see every day that
there's not much to be learned from but
if you were to look at this material in
a different way for instance look at it
under a microscope if you look at the
lid of this petri dish under a
microscope you would see this so the
color is actually coming from a ring
around each droplet near the three phase
contact line the color appears to be
size dependent and these droplets are
also very large they're tens of microns
so all of these features that we see are
incompatible with diffraction thin film
interference things that we would
normally associate with having nanoscale
periodicity so we were really interested
in this and trying to figure out what
was causing these really cool colors in
such a very simple system
so we worked with together with some
collaborators at MIT to try to figure
out what exactly was going on here
so the exact material geometry that
we're working with here of course is a
water droplet on a fairly hydrophobic
substrate so has a decently high contact
angle which makes a concave surface here
between a high refractive index water
and the low refractive index air now
anytime you go from a high refractive
index to low refractive index of course
something that can happen is total
internal reflection
so at or above a certain critical angle
all of the light can actually be
completely reflected off of this
interface from high to low refractive
index kind of like a mirror so what you
could imagine is that you know light
actually bounces around on the inside of
this surface much like how a
retroreflector would work so that could
explain how light gets reflected from
these droplets but it doesn't explain
the color so where does the color come
from of course I'm going to tell you and
when I tell you it's going to sound
fairly and perhaps intuitive or
straightforward but keep in mind that
hindsight is always 2020 so we have this
high to low refractive index microscale
curvature now depending on where the
light enters this cavity it might bounce
two times right it might bounce three
times maybe bounces four times right
there are so many different trajectories
that the light could take along this
interface just depending on the angle
it's coming in at and where it hits
along that interface all of these
trajectories are happening at the same
time okay so if we put all of these
together in one picture what we realize
is that the light that's bounced two
times three times four times it has a
different path length it has a different
phase and so it can actually interfere
with the light that's taken a different
trajectory so this is an interference
mechanism but it's an interference
mechanism that doesn't have the sort of
nano scale periodicity that you would
normally associate with structural
coloration and interference colors so so
now that we know that we can think about
harnessing this effect in materials like
droplets that you would not normally
think
about and a really nice example of this
would be in addition to obviously the
refractive index is important but the
geometry is really important too so a
really nice demonstration just take that
petri dish so there's this entire thing
of the petri dish and the black regions
have been treated to be more hydrophilic
so there's water everywhere so there's
water here but it doesn't have any color
because the contact angle is too low to
reflect the light and everywhere where
its hydrophobic can you see these colors
you do have this geometry of the water
that can support that total internal
reflection interference and so we can
diversify the materials that we can use
now that we can harness this effect in a
micro scale geometry we can access it in
situations we would not normally think
about for instance in biphasic liquid
droplets so this is a oil and oil
droplet and by tuning this interface we
can have materials for instance have
photo pattern Abul color or dynamic
color by reconfiguring the curvature of
these interfaces can also do it in solid
so you can make Meccano responsive
materials we can make particles and
films and we're really excited about the
possibilities of what we can do with
this effect now that we understand
what's causing it and how to harness it
on the micro scale so of course all of
this was really possible by just looking
at a very simple material but in a new
light pun intended so you know you might
see this now at you know on the inside
of water bottle on a hot day when you
have condensation for instance around
the inside of a Tupperware container you
might see these colors and now you'll
know what's causing them so I want to
end with a question that a friend of
mine asked me not too long ago which I
really liked which was what exists today
that could not have existed 500 years
ago and the answer of course nothing
because we have the exact same elements
we have the same laws of physics today
as we did 500 years ago and I find this
really empowering because what it means
is that whatever is going to exist 500
years from now it could exist today we
have the right building blocks we just
have to figure out
how to creatively put them together in
new and innovative ways right and
sometimes that just involves looking at
those materials from a new perspective
right so what I think is really limiting
us is our imagination and our ability to
just look at the materials around us and
be open to inspiration from even the
simplest things such as water droplets
so thank you very much for your
attention
[Applause]
